title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement [INSERT CONTACT METHOD]. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Generate a standard load profile
text: call slp_generate(), (surprise!) generate standard load profile given profile identifier, whereby several profile identifiers supported simultaneously. steps performed: Generate date sequence start_date end_date. Map day combination day period. Use result 2nd step extract values slp.3 Apply polynomial function values profile identifier H0. Return data.

title: Generate a standard load profile
text: initial step, date sequence created start_date end_date based user input. ’s simple example:

what: Map each day to a period and a weekday
title: Generate a standard load profile
text: measured load profiles analyzed study showed electricity consumption across groups fluctuates period year days within week. period definition : summer: May 15 September 14 winter: November 1 March 20 transition: March 21 May 14, September 15 October 31 also found significant difference consumption weekdays Monday Friday group. reason, days Monday Friday grouped together ‘workdays’. December 24th 31st considered Saturdays Sundays. Public holidays regarded Sundays. Note: package standardlastprofile supports public holidays Germany. retrieved nager.Date API. nationwide holidays 2024: Jan 1: New Year’s Mar 29: Good Friday Apr 1: Easter Monday May 1: Labor Day May 9: Ascension Day May 20: Whit Monday Oct 3: German Unity Day Dec 25: Christmas Day Dec 26: Boxing Day optional argument state_code can take one 16 ISO 3166-2:DE codes representing German state. allows consider holidays defined state level . result second step mapping date -called characteristic profile day, .e. combination weekday period:
code: wkday_period <- standardlastprofile:::get_wkday_period(date_seq) data.frame(input = date_seq, output = wkday_period) #>        input          output #> 1 2023-12-22  workday_winter #> 2 2023-12-23 saturday_winter #> 3 2023-12-24   sunday_winter #> 4 2023-12-25   sunday_winter #> 5 2023-12-26   sunday_winter #> 6 2023-12-27  workday_winter

what: Assign consumption values to each day
title: Generate a standard load profile
text: third step assign measurements know slp dataset characteristic profile day. job slp_generate() function: function returns data frame 4 columns: data analysis revealed load fluctuations commercial agricultural customers remain moderate throughout year. Specifically, customers customer groups labeled G0 G6, L0 L2,standard load profile can accurately derived directly 3x3 characteristic profile days available dataset slp. code snippet README, can used reproduce plot G5 profile, showcasing algorithm’s outcome:  can see, values 2023 December 24 (Sunday) December 25 26 (public holidays) identical.
code: G5 <- slp_generate(   profile_id = "G5",   start_date = "2023-12-22",   end_date = "2023-12-27"   ) head(G5) #>   profile_id          start_time            end_time watts #> 1         G5 2023-12-22 00:00:00 2023-12-22 00:15:00  50.1 #> 2         G5 2023-12-22 00:15:00 2023-12-22 00:30:00  47.4 #> 3         G5 2023-12-22 00:30:00 2023-12-22 00:45:00  44.9 #> 4         G5 2023-12-22 00:45:00 2023-12-22 01:00:00  43.3 #> 5         G5 2023-12-22 01:00:00 2023-12-22 01:15:00  43.0 #> 6         G5 2023-12-22 01:15:00 2023-12-22 01:30:00  43.8 library(ggplot2) ggplot(G5, aes(start_time, watts)) +   geom_line(color = "#0CC792") +   scale_x_datetime(     date_breaks = "1 day",     date_labels = "%b %d") +   labs(     title = "'G5': bakery with bakehouse",     subtitle = "1/4h-measurements, based on consumption of 1,000 kWh/a",     caption = "data: www.bdew.de",     x = NULL,     y = "[watts]") +   theme_minimal() +   theme(       panel.grid.minor.x = element_blank(),       panel.grid.minor.y = element_blank()   ) +   NULL

title: Generate a standard load profile
text: contrast commercial agricultural businesses, relatively even constant electricity consumption throughout year, household electricity consumption decreases winter summer vice versa (least Germany). taken account call slp_generate(). study suggested application 4th order polynomial function electric power values profile identifier H0. \[ x = x_0 \times(-3.92\mathrm{e}{-10} \times d^4 + 3.20\mathrm{e}{-7} \times  d^3 - 7.02\mathrm{e}{-5} \times d^2 + 2.10\mathrm{e}{-3} \times d + 1.24) \] : \(x\) resulting ‘dynamic’ quarter-hour value \(x_0\) static quarter-hourly value \(d\) day year integer, starting 1 January 1st values given profile H0 characteristic calculation values. multiplication 4th order polynomial function become representative - called study - dynamized load profile group household customers. following plot shows electrical power develops year profile identifier H0; clearer picture, values aggregated daily level:  Use data caution. Feel free create issues suggest improvements.

what: R Data Package for BDEW Standard Load Profiles in Electricity
title: R Data Package for BDEW Standard Load Profiles in Electricity
text: package provides data representative, standard load profiles electricity German Association Energy Water Industries (BDEW Bundesverband der Energie- und Wasserwirtschaft e.V.) tidy format.

title: R Data Package for BDEW Standard Load Profiles in Electricity
text: install development version standardlastprofile GitHub, call:

title: R Data Package for BDEW Standard Load Profiles in Electricity
text: following dataset functions implemented: slp – Dataset BDEW standard load profiles electricity slp_generate – Interface generate standard load profile, normalized annual consumption 1,000 kWh slp_info – Information examples BDEW standard load profiles

title: R Data Package for BDEW Standard Load Profiles in Electricity
text: standardlastprofile package contains one dataset called slp. total 9,504 observations 5 variables: profile_id: identifier standard load profile period: one “summer”, “winter”, “transition” day: one “saturday”, “sunday”, “workday” timestamp: format “%H:%M” watts: electric power context German electricity market, term ‘Standard Load Profile’ denotes representative pattern electricity consumption specific period. profiles portray anticipated electricity consumption diverse customer groups, like households businesses. exact match individual customer’s consumption profile, serve valid approximation larger groups similar customers. unique combination profile_id, period day 96 x 1/4 hour measurements watts. H0 keeps puzzled, alone: H0: households (German: “Haushalte”) G0 G6: commerce (“Gewerbe”) L0 L2: agriculture (“Landwirtschaft”) details, call slp_info() function.
code: str(slp) #> 'data.frame':    9504 obs. of  5 variables: #>  $ profile_id: chr  "H0" "H0" "H0" "H0" ... #>  $ period    : chr  "winter" "winter" "winter" "winter" ... #>  $ day       : chr  "saturday" "saturday" "saturday" "saturday" ... #>  $ timestamp : chr  "00:00" "00:15" "00:30" "00:45" ... #>  $ watts     : num  70.8 68.2 65.9 63.3 59.5 55 50.5 46.6 43.9 42.3 ... slp_info(language = "EN")$H0 #> $profile #> [1] "H0" #>  #> $description #> [1] "household" #>  #> $details #> [1] "This profile includes all households with exclusively and predominantly private consumption. Households with predominantly private electrical consumption, i.e. also with minor commercial consumption are e.g. sales representatives, home workers, etc. with an office in the household. The Household profile is not applicable for special applications such as storage heaters or heat pumps."

title: R Data Package for BDEW Standard Load Profiles in Electricity
text: Generate standard load profile user-defined period time using slp_generate() function:  See vignette("algorithm-step--step", package = "standardlastprofile") detailed explanation algorithm.

title: Standard Load Profile Data for Electricity from BDEW — slp
Standard Load Profile Data for Electricity from BDEW — slp
text: data.frame 9,504 observations 5 variables: profile_id character, identifier load profile, see 'Details' period character, one 'summer', 'winter', 'transition' day character, one 'saturday', 'sunday', 'workday' timestamp character, format: %H:%M watt numeric, electric power

title: Standard Load Profile Data for Electricity from BDEW — slp
text: https://www.bdew.de/energie/standardlastprofile-strom/ https://www.bdew.de/media/documents/Profile.zip https://www.bdew.de/media/documents/1999_Repraesentative-VDEW-Lastprofile.pdf https://www.bdew.de/media/documents/2000131_Anwendung-repraesentativen_Lastprofile-Step--step.pdf

title: Standard Load Profile Data for Electricity from BDEW — slp
text: 96 x 1/4h measurements electrical power combination profile_id, period day, refer "standard load profile". data determined 1999 basis 1,209 measured load profiles low-voltage customers Germany. profile identifier measurements normalized correspond annual consumption 1,000 kWh. sum quarter-hourly consumption values one year, result (approximately) 1,000 kWh/. Note values given profile H0 characteristic calculation values. multiplication 4th order polynomial function become representative dynamized load profile group household customers. fact taken care function slp_generate(), see vignette("algorithm-step--step") information. 11 standard load profiles 3 different customer groups: households: H0 commercial: G0, G1, G2, G3, G4, G5, G6 agriculture: L0, L1, L2 Call slp_info() information examples. Periods defined : summer: May 15 September 14 winter: November 1 March 20 transition: March 21 May 14, September 15 October 31 3 different characteristic days: workday: Monday Friday saturday: Saturdays; Dec 24th Dec 31th considered Saturday , Sunday sunday: Sundays public holidays Germany

title: Standard Load Profile Data for Electricity from BDEW — slp
code: head(slp) #>   profile_id period      day timestamp watts #> 1         H0 winter saturday     00:00  70.8 #> 2         H0 winter saturday     00:15  68.2 #> 3         H0 winter saturday     00:30  65.9 #> 4         H0 winter saturday     00:45  63.3 #> 5         H0 winter saturday     01:00  59.5 #> 6         H0 winter saturday     01:15  55.0

what: Generate a Standard Load Profile — slp_generate
title: Generate a Standard Load Profile — slp_generate
text: Generate standard load profile, normalized annual consumption 1,000 kWh.

title: Generate a Standard Load Profile — slp_generate
Generate a Standard Load Profile — slp_generate
text: https://www.bdew.de/energie/standardlastprofile-strom/ https://www.bdew.de/media/documents/1999_Repraesentative-VDEW-Lastprofile.pdf https://www.bdew.de/media/documents/2000131_Anwendung-repraesentativen_Lastprofile-Step--step.pdf

title: Generate a Standard Load Profile — slp_generate
text: profile_id load profile identifier, required start_date start date ISO 8601 format, required end_date end date ISO 8601 format, required state_code identifier one 16 German states, optional

title: Generate a Standard Load Profile — slp_generate
text: data.frame four variables: profile_id, character, load profile identifier start_time, POSIXct / POSIXlt, start time end_time, POSIXct / POSIXlt, end time watts, numeric, electric power

title: Generate a Standard Load Profile — slp_generate
text: regards electricity market Germany, term "Standard Load Profile" refers representative pattern electricity consumption specific period, based average consumption data. profiles used depict expected electricity consumption various customer groups, households businesses. every day, 96 x 1/4 hour measurements electrical power distinct combination profile_id, period day. Values normalized correspond annual consumption 1,000 kWh. Summing quarter-hourly consumption values one year yields approximate total 1,000 kWh/; information, refer 'Examples' section call vignette("algorithm-step--step"). total 11 representative, standard load profiles three different customer groups: Households: H0 Commercial: G0, G1, G2, G3, G4, G5, G6 Agriculture: L0, L1, L2 information examples, call slp_info(). Period definitions: summer: May 15 September 14 winter: November 1 March 20 transition: March 21 May 14, September 15 October 31 Characteristic day definitions: saturday: Saturdays; Dec 24th Dec 31th considered Saturdays Sunday. sunday: Sundays public holidays. workday: Monday Friday. Note: package supports nationwide public holidays Germany, retrieved nager.Date API. Use optional argument state_code consider public holidays state level . Possible values listed : DE-BB: Brandenburg DE-: Berlin DE-BW: Baden-Württemberg DE-: Bavaria DE-HB: Bremen DE-: Hesse DE-HH: Hamburg DE-MV: Mecklenburg-Vorpommern DE-NI: Lower-Saxony DE-NW: North Rhine-Westphalia DE-RP: Rhineland-Palatinate DE-SH: Schleswig-Holstein DE-SL: Saarland DE-SN: Saxony DE-ST: Saxony-Anhalt DE-TH: Thuringia start_date must greater equal "1990-01-01". public holidays Germany ambitious reunification 1990 (think state Berlin 1989 ). end_date must smaller equal "2073-12-31" last year supported nager.Date API.

title: Generate a Standard Load Profile — slp_generate
code: today <- Sys.Date()  # mulitple profile IDs are supported L <- slp_generate(c("L0", "L1", "L2"), today, today + 1) head(L) #>   profile_id          start_time            end_time watts #> 1         L0 2023-12-04 00:00:00 2023-12-04 00:15:00  72.4 #> 2         L0 2023-12-04 00:15:00 2023-12-04 00:30:00  69.4 #> 3         L0 2023-12-04 00:30:00 2023-12-04 00:45:00  66.9 #> 4         L0 2023-12-04 00:45:00 2023-12-04 01:00:00  64.8 #> 5         L0 2023-12-04 01:00:00 2023-12-04 01:15:00  63.2 #> 6         L0 2023-12-04 01:15:00 2023-12-04 01:30:00  61.9  # Electric power values are normalized to an annual consumption of 1,000 kWh H0_2024 <- slp_generate("H0", "2024-01-01", "2024-12-31") sum(H0_2024$watts / 4 / 1000) #> [1] 1002.084  # you can supply one of 16 ISO 3166-2:DE state codes for each German state if (FALSE) { slp_generate("H0", "2024-01-01", "2024-12-31", state = "DE-BE")  # with or without "DE-" prefix, case-insensitive slp_generate("H0", "2024-01-01", "2024-12-31", state = "BE") slp_generate("H0", "2024-01-01", "2024-12-31", state_code = "de-be") # all Berlin  # if no state code is provided then only nationwide public holidays are considered slp_generate("H0", "2024-01-01", "2024-12-31") }

title: Information and Examples of BDEW Standard Load Profiles — slp_info
code: slp_info(language = "EN")$G6 #> $profile #> [1] "G6" #>  #> $description #> [1] "weekend business" #>  #> $details #> [1] "Commercial facilities with a clear focus on consumption at weekends. In particular, these are all businesses characterized by the leisure activities of the population: youth clubs, restaurants and cafés, petrol stations with car washes, cinemas with food outlets, sports and leisure facilities." #>  slp_info(language = "DE")$G6 #> $profile #> [1] "G6" #>  #> $description #> [1] "Wochenendbetrieb" #>  #> $details #> [1] "Betriebe mit deutlichen Verbrauchsschwerpunkt an den Wochenenden. Das sind insbesondere alle durch die Freizeitaktivitäten der Bevölkerung geprägten Geschäfte: Jugendclubs, Ausflugs- und Speisegaststätten, Tankstellen mit Waschanlagen, Kinos mit Verzehr, Sport- und Freizeiteinrichtungen." #>
